qas.question: What did Neolithic people use mud-brick to build?
What scenes did the paintings on homes depict?
What were European homes constructed from?
What types of sites were built for the deceased?
Where do thousands of early tombs still exist?
What did European people use mud-brick to build?
What scenes did the people on homes depict?
What were Syrian homes constructed from?
What types of sites were built for the animals?
Where do thousands of early humans still exist?

context: Neolithic peoples in the Levant, Anatolia, Syria, northern Mesopotamia and Central Asia were also accomplished builders, utilizing mud-brick to construct <a0_0><b5_0>houses and villages<b5_0/><a0_0/>. At Çatal höyük, houses were plastered and painted with elaborate scenes of <a1_0><b6_0>humans and animals<b6_0/><a1_0/>. In Europe, long houses built from <a2_0><b7_0>wattle and daub<b7_0/><a2_0/> were constructed. <a3_0><b8_0>Elaborate tombs<b8_0/><a3_0/> were built for the dead. These tombs are particularly numerous in <a4_0><b9_0>Ireland<b9_0/><a4_0/>, where there are many thousand still in existence. Neolithic people in the British Isles built long barrows and chamber tombs for their dead and causewayed camps, henges, flint mines and cursus monuments. It was also important to figure out ways of preserving food for future months, such as fashioning relatively airtight containers, and using substances like salt as preservatives.
